article.title: Multi-Objective Genetic Algorithm Optimisation for an Array of Cherenkov Telescopes

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the peak in the 3D plot of effective area represent for this 3-telescope array?
choices: The optimal position for a single telescope.
The ideal location to observe a specific astronomical source.
Telescope arrangements corresponding to near-equilateral triangles with separations matching the Cherenkov light pool size.
The minimum separation between telescopes to avoid signal interference.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the black points forming a curve (Pareto Front) in the plot?
choices: They represent failed simulations of telescope arrangements.
They represent random telescope layouts within the defined parameter space.
They show the complete family of optimal solutions for array layout, balancing effective area and angular resolution.
They illustrate the evolution of a single array configuration over time.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the comparison between the Pareto Front and the simulated squares suggest about optimal array configurations for 4 telescopes with n=3 minimum stereo multiplicity?
choices: Square configurations are always more efficient than other geometries.
Losango configurations outperform square configurations for this specific scenario.
The performance difference between losango and square configurations is negligible.
The algorithm struggles to find optimal solutions for arrays with more than 3 telescopes.

multiple_choice_question.text: What configuration does the Pareto Front favor for a 5-telescope array based on the provided metrics?
choices: A regular pentagonal arrangement of telescopes.
Four telescopes arranged around a central fifth instrument (l=5*).
Five telescopes placed in a straight line.
A random distribution of telescopes within the defined area.
